ldc_scope.charseq: The 6.8-magnitude quake tore through the area east of Algiers, killing more than 1,600 people and leaving 7,207 injured
Left to their own devices, townspeople struggled in vain to move huge slabs of cement with their bare hands or shovels, their dying loved ones just meters (yards) away

extent.charseq: The prime minister announced 700,000 dinars (US$7,000) in aid for victims

ldc_scope.charseq: The prime minister announced 700,000 dinars (US$7,000) in aid for victims and housing for those whose homes are declared uninhabitable

extent.charseq: The government struggled to respond, moving dozens of ambulances, 3,000 police and security agents and electrical workers into the quake zone

water trucks were making the rounds to stricken villages

ldc_scope.charseq: The army was helping with tents, ambulances and engineering equipment, and water trucks were making the rounds to stricken villages

extent.charseq: U.S. President George W. Bush called Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika on Friday

ldc_scope.charseq: U.S. President George W. Bush called Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika on Friday, the official APS news agency reported, saying Bush assured Bouteflika of ``the support and friendship of the United States
The region of Boumerdes, 48 kilometers (30 miles) east of Algiers, was the hardest hit. APS, quoting the Interior Ministry, reported that 955 people died there

extent.charseq: the North African nation's deadliest since a pair of temblors west of the capital killed up to 5,000 in October 1980

ldc_scope.charseq: The 6.8-magnitude quake was the North African nation's deadliest since a pair of temblors west of the capital killed up to 5,000 in October 1980, according to the U.S. Geological Survey

The government has been battling Islamic insurgents for more than a decade and, with elections due next year, support for President Abdelaziz Bouteflika could slide if efforts to help quake survivors flag

extent.charseq: summit of world leaders in France next week

ldc_scope.charseq: To oversee rescue efforts, Bouteflika canceled plans to join a summit of world leaders in France next week, APS reported

extent.charseq: Friday as a 2-year-old girl emerged alive from the rubble of her crumbled building

ldc_scope.charseq: A pall of death, loss and pain that settled on Algeria two days after a devastating earthquake lifted briefly Friday as a 2-year-old girl emerged alive from the rubble of her crumbled building, spared by the caprices of fate
